author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: Europe’s Economic Recovery Is a Summer Memory
description: As the coronavirus resumes spreading rapidly across the continent, hopes for an economic revival have given way to diminished expectations.
content: LONDON — What faint hopes remained that Europe was recovering from the economic catastrophe delivered by the pandemic have disappeared as the lethal virus has resumed spreading rapidly across much of the continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The 1619 Chronicles
description: Journalism does better when it writes the first rough draft of history, not the last word on it.
content: If there’s one word admirers and critics alike can agree on when it comes to The New York Times’s award-winning 1619 Project, it’s ambition. Ambition to reframe America’s conversation about race. Ambition to reframe our understanding of history. Ambition to move from news pages to classrooms. Ambition to move from scholarly debate to national consciousness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Iga Swiatek Steamrolls Through the French Open, Besting Sofia Kenin in the Final
description: Swiatek became the first player from Poland to win a Grand Slam singles title. She did it without losing a set at Roland Garros, and no more than five games in any match.
content: PARIS — The Polish national anthem reverberated through a mostly empty Philippe Chatrier Court to the delight of Iga Swiatek, who had barely broken a sweat in her 6-4, 6-1 defeat of the No. 4 seed and reigning Australian Open champion Sofia Kenin in their French Open singles final on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allyson Waller and Bryan Pietsch
title: Former Philadelphia Officer Charged With Murder in 2017 Shooting
description: Eric Ruch Jr.’s killing of Dennis Plowden, an unarmed Black man, after a high-speed chase was unjustified, a grand jury found.
content: A former Philadelphia police officer has been charged with first-degree murder in connection with the fatal shooting of an unarmed Black man after a high-speed chase in December 2017 that ended in a crash, prosecutors said Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Warning: Don’t Touch This Hairy-Looking Caterpillar
description: Contact with a puss caterpillar can cause a painful reaction as well as a rash, fever, muscle cramps or swollen glands, experts caution.
content: First, it was murder hornets. Now it’s stinging caterpillars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Maggie Haberman, Katie Benner, Lara Jakes and Michael S. Schmidt
title: Election Less Than a Month Away, Trump Leans on Barr and Pompeo for a Lift
description: The secretary of state said he would make Hillary Clinton’s emails public, handing the president a weapon to attack his political foes as the attorney general resisted his overtures to prosecute them.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump forced the State Department on Friday to commit to releasing at least some of Hillary Clinton’s emails before next month’s election, resurrecting a four-year-old issue in hopes that it would prove as helpful to his political prospects as it was when he defeated her in 2016.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Battle Cry
description: Brian Thomas hits us squarely with a piercing Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This grid is really loopy and fun; it’s the fourth construction we’ve seen from Brian Thomas this year, the kind of statistic that honestly impresses the heck out of 2020 me. I wrestled with at least one entry in all four corners — tough trivia, a bemusing misdirect, an odd letter sequence and an unfamiliar term. There are lots of sparklers in between the stumpers, adding up to an entertaining solve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Dooley
title: A Famed Horror Director Mines Japan’s Real-Life Atrocities
description: Kiyoshi Kurosawa’s latest movie, which recently won him the award for best director at the Venice Film Festival, is a thriller animated by the ghosts of Japan’s ghastly wartime experiments.
content: TOKYO — The director Kiyoshi Kurosawa is best known for horror movies depicting the dark undercurrents of life in modern Japan and the vengeful ghosts that haunt it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch and Concepción de León
title: Fatal Shooting in Denver Amid Dueling Protests, Police Say
description: The shooting happened as opposing rallies by far-right and far-left activists were ending. A television news station reported that a private security guard it had hired was being detained by the police.
content: DENVER — One person was fatally shot in Denver on Saturday against the backdrop of opposing rallies between far-right and far-left activists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Democrats, Facing Critical Supreme Court Battle, Worry Feinstein Is Not Up to the Task
description: Ms. Feinstein, 87, has slowed in recent years and limited her public profile, leading some Democrats to wonder if she can lead them through a consequential confirmation process.
content: When Senator Dianne Feinstein of California, the top Democrat on the Judiciary Committee about to plunge into an election-season Supreme Court confirmation battle, was asked in the Capitol last week what her strategy would be for the coming fight, she walked by silently, an aide offering that she had a meeting to attend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: A Convicted Kidnapper Is Chosen to Lead Government of Kyrgyzstan
description: Lawmakers in Central Asia's only democracy selected a man sprung from jail by protesters just days ago in an effort to end days of violent political unrest
content: MOSCOW — A man who had been convicted of kidnapping was chosen to be the prime minister of Kyrgyzstan on Saturday after feuding politicians agreed on a new government in an effort to end nearly a week of violent turmoil in the Central Asian country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: This Miami Heat Player Rained 3-Pointers on the Lakers’ Parade
description: The Los Angeles Lakers expected to win a championship on Friday, but they were denied by the hot shooting of Miami’s Duncan Robinson (and, of course, Jimmy Butler).
content: LAKE BUENA VISTA, Fla. — Duncan Robinson was struggling with his 3-point shot in the N.B.A. finals, and that was a problem because shooting 3-pointers is the one thing he does exceptionally well. Jimmy Butler, his teammate on the Miami Heat, invited him to his hotel room for a late-night chat. It was a pep talk with a heavy dose of tough love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Manic Panic on the Potomac
description: Will Mitch ditch the Donald?
content: WASHINGTON — At long last, a top Republican is distancing himself from Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Leibovich
title: Trump Has Called His Supporters ‘Disgusting.’ Do They Care?
description: “The people Trump despises most love him the most,” Howard Stern has said. But that may be beginning to change.
content: WASHINGTON — Sitting in the back of his limousine after an appearance on “The Tonight Show,” Donald Trump was explaining to me why he never had much use for Jimmy Carter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: For Boris Johnson, and Maybe Trump, Covid as Metaphor Is Hard to Shake
description: The British prime minister’s personal battle with the disease has come to symbolize his government’s fumbling efforts to halt the pathogen.
content: LONDON — President Trump got a well-wishing phone call this past week from one of the few foreign leaders who knows what he’s been going through: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, the survivor of a serious brush with the coronavirus this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Grullón Paz
title: 2020 Election Presidential Debate Calendar: Key Dates
description: Here’s the who, what, when and where for the three matchups between President Trump and Joe Biden and the single vice-presidential debate.
content: Like many things this year, the presidential and vice-presidential debates have looked a little different. And thanks to the coronavirus and a host of political developments, the remaining debates on the schedule are now in flux.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Airline Miles Programs Sure Are Profitable. Are You the Loser?
description: United and Delta have been boasting to lenders about fat margins in frequent-flier mile programs. Time for customers to pay a bit more attention.
content: The airlines of the United States have extra-special status. How special? Many of them may get a second pile of coronavirus relief money before citizens who can’t afford to fly get another $1,200 check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Fighting Eases, Briefly, After Cease-Fire Between Armenia and Azerbaijan
description: The Armenian Defense Ministry said most of the front line was “relatively calm.” But renewed shelling was reported at night.
content: GORIS, Armenia — Fierce fighting over a breakaway Armenian enclave in Azerbaijan partly subsided on Saturday after a cease-fire took effect. But there was little expectation of a durable peace two weeks into the most violent conflict that the volatile region has seen in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Nevada Revokes Halt on Rapid Antigen Testing in Nursing Homes
description: The reversal came just hours after the federal government threatened the state, calling the prohibition on the tests “illegal.”
content: Under pressure from the federal government, Nevada health officials on Friday rescinded a statewide order directing nursing homes to halt the use of two government-issued rapid coronavirus tests that the state had deemed to be inaccurate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: Coronavirus Safety Runs Into a Stubborn Barrier: Masculinity
description: When political leaders suggest basic precautions appear unmanly, men are less likely to follow health and safety advice, experts say.
content: On Tuesday, and not for the first time, Joseph R. Biden Jr. described President Trump’s reluctant attitude toward wearing masks as “macho.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Nick Corasaniti and Stephanie Saul
title: Huge Absentee Vote in Key States Favors Democrats So Far
description: In Wisconsin, about 146,000 people voted by mail in the 2016 general election. This fall, about 647,000 people have already voted absentee, many in Democratic strongholds.
content: In Madison, Wis., thousands of people have gone to parks to deliver their ballots during Saturday voting festivals. In Milwaukee, Facebook feeds are inundated with selfies of Democrats inserting ballots into drop boxes. And along the shores of Lake Superior, voters in Wisconsin’s liberal northwest corner still trust the Postal Service to deliver ballots.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: It’s Djokovic-Nadal Yet Again. But This French Open Duel Is Not Like the Others.
description: Rafael Nadal has been essentially unstoppable on clay. Novak Djokovic, though, could be that stopper.
content: Men’s tennis finally got a new Grand Slam champion in New York last month as Dominic Thiem, an Austrian in, of all things, his 20s won the United States Open.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salim Valji
title: With Push on Diversity, N.H.L. Makes Landmark Selection of Black Player
description: Quinton Byfield became the highest-drafted Black player in league history just one day before the Hockey Diversity Alliance said it would work independently of the N.H.L.
content: After an N.H.L. season in which players challenged deep-seated issues of racism and the lack of diversity within the sport, the league made history this week when Quinton Byfield became the highest-drafted Black player.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Without Live Music to Play, Pearl Jam Reimagines Rock Activism in 2020
description: The pandemic has grounded rock tours and left clubs empty. So Pearl Jam is turning to the tools of modern politics to get out the vote.
content: Back in March, as the coronavirus first gripped the country, Pearl Jam made the difficult decision to postpone all its concert dates for the foreseeable future. In doing so, the band was canceling not just a fall tour, but also a trip through presidential battleground states like Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin that would have doubled as a get-out-the-vote campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Trump’s Overhaul of Immigration Is Worse Than You Think
description: This administration has attacked every aspect of the immigration system — and it won’t be easy to undo.
content: It was a kind gesture to some 6,000 Filipinos who, in their youth, had fought with American armed forces in World War II and had been granted U.S. citizenship decades later. In 2016, when the veterans were in their 80s and 90s, the Obama administration agreed to allow some of their relatives in the Philippines to come to the United States before they completed the long wait for formal admission.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles
title: Facing Disaster After Disaster, the American Red Cross C.E.O. Stays Optimistic
description: “I really believe when we’re all set free from captivity, we are going to be so happy and kind to each other,” Gail McGovern says.
content: When Gail McGovern took over the American Red Cross in 2008, the organization was running a deficit and tarnished by scandal. Annual budget shortfalls ran into the hundreds of millions, and her predecessor was ousted after having an inappropriate relationship with a subordinate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump Makes First Public Appearance Since Leaving Walter Reed
description: The president continued to play down the threat of the virus, but the event that the White House had previewed as a huge “peaceful protest for law and order” was uncharacteristically brief.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House had not made public the results of President Trump’s latest coronavirus test, which he claims he took on Friday. But Mr. Trump, eager to prove he had fully recovered a week after being hospitalized for Covid-19, appeared briefly on Saturday afternoon in front of hundreds of chanting supporters gathered at the White House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon send us way back in time.
content: ACROSTIC — This is another toughie, I’d say, unless you’ve got some serious American history chops (and that includes south of our border). The passage is from a 21st-century book, “1491,” by Charles C. Mann, a science and technology journalist; it concerns one of the great Mesoamerican civilizations, the Olmec, who lived in a greatly sophisticated culture before both the Mayas and the Aztecs.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Son of the City, and Cornerstone of a Dynasty
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, October 10, 2020.
content: “He was like a master chess player who used his brain to take the bat right out of my hands.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Martin
title: Trump, down for a week with coronavirus, returns to rallying with large White House gathering.
description: Just over a week after President Trump tested positive for the coronavirus, he is about to start holding rallies again.
content: Just over a week since he was hospitalized with Covid-19, President Trump is returning to his beloved rallies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert P. Baird
title: Can Trump Really Speed Approval of Covid Treatments?
description: Emergency-use authorizations, a formerly obscure corner of regulatory law, have become a centerpiece of the government’s response to the pandemic.
content: In a five-minute video posted to his Twitter account on Wednesday, President Trump stood in front of the White House and offered a lavish endorsement for a treatment he had received while hospitalized at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Senate Republicans Denounce White House’s Offer for Coronavirus Relief
description: Even as Democrats held out for more concessions over funding and provisions, it was the deep divisions among Republicans that were standing in the way.
content: WASHINGTON — Republicans revolted on Saturday over President Trump’s efforts to resuscitate bipartisan stimulus talks with a $1.8 trillion offer to Democrats, balking at what they called an exorbitantly costly plan in the latest sign of steep obstacles to any deal before the election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: For Boris Johnson, and maybe Trump, Covid as metaphor is hard to shake.
description: President Trump got a well-wishing phone call this past week from one of the few foreign leaders who knows what he’s been going through: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, the survivor of a serious brush with the coronavirus this spring.
content: President Trump got a well-wishing phone call this past week from one of the few foreign leaders who knows what he’s been going through: Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain, the survivor of a serious brush with the coronavirus this spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Rays Send Yankees to Another Off-Season of Vexing Questions
description: Mike Brosseau’s eighth-inning homer was the difference on Friday, but the Yankees again were left to analyze how a talented roster fell short in the playoffs.
content: SAN DIEGO — The timing was coincidental, but fitting nonetheless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump says he is ‘medication free’ in an interview with Fox News.
description: The president claimed that he went to the hospital last Friday because he “didn’t feel strong,” but denied that he had experienced any trouble breathing, although there had been congestion in his lungs.
content: President Trump, in his first televised interview since he announced that he had tested positive for the coronavirus, said Friday night that he was “medication free” and back to normal, a week after he was hospitalized after having trouble breathing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner
title: Justice Dept. Suspends All Diversity and Inclusion Training for Staff
description: The move was the latest effort by the Trump administration to eliminate any training that encourages workers to acknowledge that implicit racial and gender biases exist in the workplace.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department suspended all diversity and inclusion training for its employees and managers this week, complying with President Trump’s recent executive order to eliminate any training that suggests that implicit racial and gender biases exist in the workplace, according to a memo distributed to the department’s executive officers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Extra Pounds May Raise Risk of Severe Covid-19
description: Even people who aren’t obese may be more likely to become seriously ill when infected with the coronavirus, the C.D.C. said.
content: Obese Americans are more likely to become dangerously ill if they are infected with the new coronavirus. Now public health officials are warning that a much broader segment of the population also may be at risk: even moderately excess weight may increase the odds of severe disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: For the Astros, One Final Hurdle to a Defiant World Series Return
description: Despite a losing record in the regular season, Houston has blitzed through the postseason and reached the A.L.C.S., where a crafty Rays squad awaits.
content: There was symbolism in the timing when Major League Baseball announced a new, expanded postseason format. The league made it official on opening day in July, while the very first game of the season was already in progress. The message: We know this won’t last very long, but wait till we get to the fall!
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Federal Judge Blocks Texas Governor’s Move to Limit Ballot Drop-Off Sites
description: Gov. Greg Abbott had ordered that counties in the state be limited to one site each.
content: A federal judge in Texas on Friday blocked Gov. Greg Abbott’s move to limit counties in the state to one ballot drop-off site each.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Mike Ives
title: Hong Kong Arrests Nine Over Protesters’ Escape by Speedboat
description: The arrests appeared intended to deter others from helping antigovernment protesters flee the Chinese territory, where Beijing’s grip is tightening.
content: HONG KONG — The Hong Kong police said on Saturday that they had arrested nine people accused of helping a group of protesters, who were later intercepted by the mainland Chinese authorities, flee the city in August by speedboat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and Giulia McDonnell Nieto del Rio
title: Hurricane Delta Brings Floods and Destruction to an Already Battered Louisiana
description: The storm made landfall some 20 miles from where Laura touched down a few weeks ago, intensifying the devastation the state has experienced during a brutal hurricane season.
content: BELL CITY, La. — Hurricane Delta tore across Louisiana late Friday, leaving a trail of destruction as it turned roadways into rapids and uprooted trees that crashed onto roofs. It also dealt a demoralizing blow to a state still staggering its way back from one of the most powerful storms that it had ever endured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Guantánamo Bay Navy Base Raises Health Alert and Closes Facilities
description: Residents received little information about the source of the health scare that halted activities at the outpost in Cuba.
content: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman, Annie Karni, Katherine J. Wu and Michael Cooper
title: Trump sent more than 2,000 invitations for an event on the White House lawn on Saturday.
description: President Trump is planning to host up to 2,000 people on the South Lawn of the White House on Saturday for his first in-person event since he announced he had tested positive for the coronavirus, three people familiar with the plans said on Friday, and his campaign announced that he would hold a rally in Florida on Monday.
content: President Trump is planning to host up to 2,000 people on the South Lawn of the White House on Saturday for his first in-person event since he announced he had tested positive for the coronavirus, three people familiar with the plans said on Friday, and his campaign announced that he would hold a rally in Florida on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Gendler
title: 2020 French Open: Women’s Final Preview
description: Sofia Kenin and Iga Swiatek face off, each looking to secure their first French Open title.
content: How to watch: 9 a.m. on NBC; streaming on the NBC app.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Crispy Sour Cream and Onion Chicken Forever
description: Make Ali Slagle’s recipe, or any of the top recipes of the week.
content: This weekend make Ali Slagle’s dip-inspired crispy sour cream and onion chicken (above), Dorie Greenspan’s lemon goop or Kay Chun’s roasted salmon with miso rice and ginger-scallion vinaigrette. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlotte Cowles
title: The Week in Business: A Conspiracy Crackdown
description: Big tech is trying to stop the spread of misinformation. But is it too little, too late?
content: The days are getting shorter, the election is getting closer and retailers are preparing for a truly weird holiday season. Here’s what you need to know in business and tech for the week ahead. — Charlotte Cowles
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: πr²
description: Gary Larson’s Sunday puzzle makes us circle back and get square.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — Today’s grid hangs on an interesting angle, one that you’ll miss if you don’t notice its title — πr² — or remember that this mathematical term describes the area of a circle (with a radius of r). Its constructor, Gary Larson, is a former cruise ship entertainer, not a cartoonist; this is only his fourth Times puzzle, but he’s prolific elsewhere, including The Los Angeles Times. This is also his Sunday debut with us; it’s heavy with theme and there are a lot of unusual entries to buoy the fill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 7 Key Findings About Trump’s Reinvented Swamp
description: The president built a system of favor-seeking at his hotels and resorts that is unrivaled in modern American politics.
content: [The findings below are from an investigative article on the president’s taxes. Read a note from Dean Baquet, the executive editor, on earlier installments in the series.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Will This Be the Last French Open With Only Human Eyes Minding the Lines?
description: Clay-court events have been the last holdouts against electronic line calling, in large part because of how well the surface absorbs marks wherever a ball lands.
content: A ball lands close to a line. A call is made. A player expresses doubt. A chair umpire descends to inspect the ball mark on the red clay and renders final judgment, often with the umpire and the player both hunched over the evidence in the soil like archaeologists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: North Korea Unveils What Appears to Be New ICBM During Military Parade
description: The weapon appeared to be bigger than the North’s previous long-range missile, indicating that it might be able to fly farther with a more powerful nuclear warhead. But it is untested.
content: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea displayed what appeared to be its largest-ever intercontinental ballistic missile during a nighttime military parade in Pyongyang on Saturday, but it was not immediately clear if the missile would work or was for show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rob Henderson
title: Everything I Know About Elite America I Learned From ‘Fresh Prince’ and ‘West Wing’
description: Television taught me how to move between social classes — but at what cost?
content: At first, I thought class was about money. “The Fresh Prince of Bel-Air” taught me that it wasn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Domenic Parisi Dies at 76; He Sheared Nixon’s Locks
description: Born in Sicily, he trained as a farrier but became a barber in New Jersey, where his most famous client was the former president. He died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Harlan
title: Teenagers in Turmoil
description: Whether undead, unloved or unjustly incarcerated, these star-crossed young-adult protagonists face their demons.
content: MIDNIGHT SUNBy Stephenie Meyer672 pp. Little, Brown. $27.99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tamar Adler
title: It’s a Hellscape Out There. Try a Galette.
description: They’re messy. They’re forgiving. They’re the pastry form we need in 2020.
content: After six months at home, I have no idea what I sound like on the page anymore. I’ve lost my voice to underuse — or that’s what it feels like. I don’t know what I look like either. It’s not that I’m sitting around in my pajamas. I’m getting as dressed as I ever did, even putting on perfume. But without daily immersion in society, my sense of the world’s outside-in gaze on me has attenuated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Astead W. Herndon
title: Trump, Lagging in Polls, Tries to Project Strength: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: President Trump returned to the White House this week after his hospitalization for coronavirus. He is eager to get back on the campaign trail as his support is falling far behind Joe Biden in national polls.
content: Welcome to our weekly analysis of the state of the 2020 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump Claims in Interview That He Is ‘Medication Free’
description: The president said on Fox that he went to Walter Reed National Military Medical Center last Friday because he “didn’t feel strong,” but he denied that he had experienced any trouble breathing.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Friday night in his first televised interview since he learned he had Covid-19 that he was “medication free” and he claimed to be back to normal, a week after being hospitalized after having trouble breathing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Fazio
title: Princeton to Name Residential College After Black Alumna
description: It will be named after Mellody Hobson and built where a college once bore Woodrow Wilson’s name. Princeton in June said the former president was a racist who segregated the Civil Service.
content: On the site of a residential college that for more than 50 years bore the name of Woodrow Wilson, the president who oversaw the segregation of the federal Civil Service, a new Princeton residential college will be built and named after Mellody Hobson, a prominent Black alumna, the university said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg
title: Battered by Trump, the C.D.C.’s Director Faces Pressure to Speak Out
description: The agency prides itself on avoiding Washington partisanship. But the White House has successfully pushed the agency to revise guidelines on matters like school reopenings and church gatherings.
content: WASHINGTON — Pressure is mounting on the leaders of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention — from inside and outside the agency — to speak publicly against the White House’s manhandling of C.D.C. research and public health decisions, with career scientists so demoralized they are talking of quitting if President Trump wins re-election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeff Sommer
title: How to Hold Onto Your Money, Wherever the Market Takes You
description: Crises abound, yet stocks have generated strong returns. Investors had better be ready for anything.
content: Optimism in investing these days often resembles the pessimism of only a few years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: A.O.C.’s Mistake in Pulling Out of a Rabin Memorial
description: How politicians cave in an age of absolutist moral judgments.
content: Robert Mackey of The Intercept tweeted this week: “I give up. It’s pointless to report on anything other than the president of the United States having a personal social media feed that reveals he’s a lunatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Can a Broker Change the Details to Make an Old Listing Look New?
description: What difference does it make if an apartment is called 13P or 13D? A big one to many prospective renters, which is why brokers sometimes change those numbers.
content: Q: I live in a rental building on the Upper West Side and follow the building’s listings on StreetEasy. Like many buildings, it has had multiple listings that have been up for a long time. I now see that the brokers have changed the letters of the apartments so that they appear as new listings. For example, apartment 13D is now listed as 13P. (Our building only has apartments lettered A through K.) They have done this with a couple of apartments. Is this legal?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters and Michael M. Grynbaum
title: As Trump Recovers, He Retreats to a Conservative Media Safe Space
description: The president is opting for settings where there is virtually no risk he will encounter an uncomfortable question, but in doing so he is missing a chance to talk to a broader range of voters.
content: When President Trump picked someone to conduct his first on-camera interview since testing positive for the coronavirus, he made the safest of choices: Dr. Marc Siegel, a physician and Fox News personality who has criticized Democratic governors for closing down schools and businesses to fight the pandemic and declared that Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s leading infectious disease expert, is “there to serve the president.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: There Will Be No Trump Coup
description: A final pre-election case for understanding the president as a noisy weakling, not a budding autocrat.
content: Three weeks from now, we will reach an end to speculation about what Donald Trump will do if he faces political defeat, whether he will leave power like a normal president or attempt some wild resistance. Reality will intrude, substantially if not definitively, into the argument over whether the president is a corrupt incompetent who postures as a strongman on Twitter or a threat to the Republic to whom words like “authoritarian” and even “autocrat” can be reasonably applied.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Who’s the Tax Cheat: The Lady in Jail or the Man in the White House?
description: Donald Trump knows that taxes are for the poor.
content: While reading that President Trump had claimed $70,000 in highly dubious tax deductions for hair styling for his television show, I kept thinking about a homeless African-American woman named Tanya McDowell who was imprisoned for misleading officials to get her young son into a better school district.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger
title: Taking Page From Authoritarians, Trump Turns Power of State Against Political Rivals
description: President Trump took a step even Richard M. Nixon avoided in his most desperate days: openly ordering direct, immediate government action against specific opponents, timed to serve his re-election campaign.
content: President Trump’s order to his secretary of state to declassify thousands of Hillary Clinton’s emails, along with his insistence that his attorney general issue indictments against Barack Obama and Joseph R. Biden Jr., takes his presidency into new territory — until now, occupied by leaders with names like Putin, Xi and Erdogan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: James Murdoch, Rebellious Scion
description: Increasingly uncomfortable with News Corp’s politics and profit motives, Rupert’s younger son chose chickens and sheep over Fox, and insists he doesn’t watch ‘Succession.’
content: WASHINGTON — As we sat down to lunch in my garden, I mentioned to James Murdoch that I’ve been reading a lot of classical plays lately and a popular theme is the rancorous battle between two brothers over a kingdom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert P. Baird
title: Can Trump really speed up approval of Covid treatments?
description: In a five-minute video posted to his Twitter account on Wednesday, President Trump stood in front of the White House and offered a lavish endorsement for a treatment he had received while hospitalized at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.
content: In a five-minute video posted to his Twitter account on Wednesday, President Trump stood in front of the White House and offered a lavish endorsement for a treatment he had received while hospitalized at Walter Reed National Military Medical Center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Augugliaro
title: Not Sure Who to Vote For? Seriously? OK, This Quiz Is for You
description: In a time of extreme political polarization, there is still somehow you, the undecided voter.  The team here at Opinion has created a helpful flowchart to put this agonizing decision to bed.
content: In a time of extreme political polarization, there is still somehow you, the undecided voter.  The team here at Opinion has created a helpful flowchart to put this agonizing decision to bed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Confessore, Karen Yourish, Steve Eder, Ben Protess, Maggie Haberman, Grace Ashford, Michael LaForgia, Kenneth P. Vogel, Michael Rothfeld and Larry Buchanan
title: The Swamp That Trump Built
description: A businessman-president transplanted favor-seeking in Washington to his family’s hotels and resorts — and earned millions as a gatekeeper to his own administration.
content: A businessman-president transplanted favor-seeking in Washington to his family’s hotels and resorts — and earned millions as a gatekeeper to his own administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio, John Keefe, Amy Schoenfeld Walker and Katherine J. Wu
title: How Long Should Trump Be in Isolation?
description: Some White House staff members who were exposed to the virus have not followed public health guidance to quarantine or self-isolate.
content: Some White House staff members who were exposed to the virus have not followed public health guidance to quarantine or self-isolate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press and Storyful
title: Hurricane Delta Brings High Winds and Rain to Louisiana’s Coast
description: Storm surge rose more than seven feet on Friday in some areas of Louisiana, where Hurricane Delta made landfall as a Category 2 storm. It struck 20 miles east of Hurricane Laura’s landfall six weeks earlier.
content: Storm surge rose more than seven feet on Friday in some areas of Louisiana, where Hurricane Delta made landfall as a Category 2 storm. It struck 20 miles east of Hurricane Laura’s landfall six weeks earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Amazon Power Plant: A Company Responds
description: Norte Energia discusses how its deployment of the hydroelectric power plant in the Brazilian state of Pará has been guided by respect for the local Indigenous populations.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Oct. 10, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Oct. 10, 2020.
content: An article on Friday about President Trump’s criticism of his top officials for not prosecuting or implicating his political enemies referred incorrectly to a video of the president speaking on the White House lawn. While on first inspection it appeared that the backdrop might have been on a loop, a deeper examination by The Times and by Catalin Grigoras, a director at the National Center for Media Forensics at the University of Colorado, Denver, indicated no evidence of manipulation.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Election Problems, and Solutions
description: With three weeks to go, readers offer ideas to surmount obstacles in the way of a smooth vote.
